article.headline: Covid-19 booster jab results raise hopes of beating Omicron
article.label: CORONAVIRUS
article.shortHeadline: Jab results boost hopes of beating Omicron
article.strapline: Third dose gives immune system a massive lift

attributes.value: Booster jabs “massively” strengthen the body’s defences against Covid, according to key results that have raised hopes of
Booster jabs “massively” strengthen the body’s defences against Covid, according to key results that have raised hopes of strong protection from the Omicron variant.
A third dose not only increased antibody levels thirtyfold, but roughly tripled levels of T-cells, a part of the immune system that
Booster jabs “massively” strengthen the body’s defences against Covid, according to key results that have raised hopes of strong protection from the Omicron variant.

A third dose not only increased antibody levels thirtyfold, but roughly tripled levels of T-cells, a part of the immune system that experts believe could be the critical weapon against the heavily mutated Omicron strain.
• Germany has imposed a de-facto lockdown on the unvaccinated
• EU health chiefs estimate that Omicron could displace Delta by the spring
• The total number of Omicron case across Britain has risen to 42
• Omicron has become dominant in South Africa as infection rates surge

article.headline: Old Bexley & Sidcup by-election result: Warning for Tories as they hold seat with slashed majority
article.shortHeadline: Slashed majority in Old Bexley & Sidcup is a warning for Tories

attributes.value: Boris Johnson and his cabinet will conduct a canvassing “blitz” before a crucial by-election later this month amid fears
Boris Johnson and his cabinet will conduct a canvassing “blitz” before a crucial by-election later this month amid fears there will be a poor turnout of Conservative voters.
The Tories held Old Bexley & Sidcup today despite low numbers heading to the polls but ministers are worried that another by-election in two weeks could go close to the wire.
On December 16 voters in North Shropshire will choose an MP to succeed Owen Paterson, who quit last month over a sleaze scandal.
Oliver Dowden, the Conservative party co-chairman, told Tory MPs it would be a “harder” contest than that in Bexley, southeast London.
The Conservatives held Old Bexley & Sidcup, a safe Tory seat, with a significantly reduced majority on a turnout of only 34

article.headline: Arthur Labinjo-Hughes murder: stepmother jailed for life
article.label: Arthur Labinjo-Hughes
article.shortHeadline: ‘Sadistic’ stepmother to serve life for torture and murder of six-year-old boy

attributes.value: The mother of a boy murdered by his stepmother said yesterday that his death had destroyed her life.
The mother of a boy murdered by his stepmother said yesterday that his death had destroyed her life.
Olivia Labinjo-Halcrow, who was jailed two years ago for stabbing her partner to death, used a victim-impact statement written from her cell to describe how the killing of her six-year-old son
had left her bereft. “Arthur was my life and my reason for living,” she said.

Her son ended up in the care of his father, Thomas Hughes, and later his girlfriend Emma Tustin. Coventry crown court was told that the couple oversaw a “campaign of cruelty” in which the boy was isolated, forced to eat salt-laced meals and suffered 130 injuries. Tustin, 32, inflicted an unsurvivable brain injury at her home in Solihull, West

article.headline: Google delays return to office over Omicron concerns
article.label: CORONAVIRUS
article.shortHeadline: Google delays return to office over Omicron concerns

attributes.value: Google has again pushed back plans to draw staff back to the office amid concern over the spread of Covid-19’s Omicron variant.

The American technology group, which has more than 150,000 employees across the world, will not mandate that they return to their desks in the new year. A voluntary return policy had been due to expire on January 10.
Matt Brittin, Google’s president for Europe, the Middle East and Africa, told workers yesterday that this deadline would be postponed. His message was first reported by

Alphabet, owner of Google, is based in Mountain View, California, valued at $1.9 trillion and has more than 80 offices worldwide. It makes more money from digital advertising than any other company, selling space on its search

article.headline: Mercedes in row over Grenfell firm Kingspan
article.shortHeadline: Mercedes in row over Grenfell firm

attributes.value: A “truly shocking” sponsorship of Lewis Hamilton’s Formula One team by the firm that made combustible
has been sharply criticised by Michael Gove.

Kingspan was named as a partner of the Mercedes-AMG Petronas Formula One team, for whom the seven-times world champion is the star driver. The company’s branding will be on Hamilton’s car at Sunday’s Saudi Arabia Grand Prix. The decision was described as “truly shocking” by survivors of the fire, which killed 72 people in June 2017.

Gove, the secretary of state for levelling up, housing and communities, said he was “deeply disappointed” by the sponsorship. In a tweet last night, Gove wrote: “I will be writing to Mercedes to ask them to reconsider. The Grenfell community deserves

article.headline: Storm Arwen: Troops sent to help thousands without power
article.shortHeadline: Troops sent to help thousands without power

attributes.value: Royal Marine commandos have been deployed to help with the recovery operation in the
Royal Marine commandos have been deployed to help with the recovery operation in the
following the “extensive and catastrophic damage” caused by the storm.
More than 100 military personnel from the three services are being sent to northern regions of Scotland to make door-to-door checks on over 4,000 homes believed to have lost power and water supplies.

According to a councillor in Northumberland, the storm has claimed a further life. Steven Bridgett said that while the person from the Rothbury area had underlying health conditions, it was thought “the lack of power/heating may have been a contributing factor”.
At least three people have already died since last Friday as a result of the

article.headline: Tui flight came within seconds of crash
article.shortHeadline: Tui flight came within seconds of crash

attributes.value: A Tui aircraft came within seconds of crashing into the ground in September, it has been revealed.

Air accident investigators are examining whether a lack of flying hours, caused by a pause in operations during the pandemic, contributed to the “serious incident” in which the aircraft descended rapidly towards the ground at Aberdeen.

Tui flight BY8YE, from Palma de Mallorca to Aberdeen, was on approach to land on September 11 when air traffic controllers ordered it to “go around” because a search-and-rescue helicopter needed priority to take off.

The pilots were told to climb from 2,600ft above sea level to 3,000ft and turn left, before circling back for a second approach. They followed the order, retracting the landing gear and climbing to the stated altitude.

article.headline: Emotional upset and exertion could prompt strokes
article.shortHeadline: How losing your cool or overdoing it at the gym could trigger a stroke

attributes.value: Anger, upset or strenuous physical exertion may act as triggers for strokes, a significant study suggests.
One in 11 sufferers had experienced a period of anger or upset in the hour leading up to their stroke, researchers found.
One patient in 20 had engaged in heavy physical exertion, according to the Interstroke study, the largest research project of its kind.
A team led by the National University of Ireland, Galway (NUI Galway), looked at 13,462 cases of stroke in 32 countries, including the UK and Ireland.

Andrew Smyth, professor of clinical epidemiology at the university and a consultant nephrologist at Galway University Hospitals, said: “Stroke prevention is a priority for physicians, and despite advances it remains difficult to predict when a stroke will occur.

article.headline: Volunteers on a mission in the fens to save 100 ‘cheeky’ corncrake chicks
article.shortHeadline: Volunteers on a mission in the fens to save 100 cheeky chicks

attributes.value: Billie Rate had no idea what a corncrake was — “I’d never heard of them” — and even less experience in conservation.
Billie Rate had no idea what a corncrake was — “I’d never heard of them” — and even less experience in conservation.
“I’m used to handling chickens on our farm, or shooing out a swallow if it flies inside but certainly nothing like this,” she said

Yet, last summer, she found herself caring for 100 “cheeky” corncrake chicks in Norfolk. Considering just 870 calling males were recorded last year across the whole of the UK, most of them clinging on by a tailfeather at the very edges of the Outer Hebrides, the future of the species sat, quite literally, in her hands.
Rate, 34, Debbie Parsons, 56, Emma Brand, 37, and Rosie Siverns, 23, usually work in the shop and café of the Welney Wetlands
, Cape Town | Debbie White | David Brown

article.headline: Call for higher tax on household gas to meet Cop26 carbon pledge
article.shortHeadline: Call for higher tax on gas bills to meet carbon pledge

attributes.value: Tax on gas used for home heating and cooking should be increased to help the UK fulfil commitments made at the Cop26 climate
Tax on gas used for home heating and cooking should be increased to help the UK fulfil commitments made at the Cop26 climate conference, according to the government’s climate change advisers.
The Climate Change Committee said the government must “walk the talk” and introduce policies to meet its targets for cutting emissions.
In a report on the outcome of the
, the committee called on the Treasury to review the role of the tax system in delivering the UK’s legally binding target of net zero emissions by 2050.
The review should consider “the role of tax in achieving a higher and more consistent carbon price across the economy”, the committee said.
It made clear it considered the reduced rate of 5 per cent

article.headline: Sharon Graham: New Unite chief threatens to cut Labour’s funding over shadow cabinet reshuffle
article.shortHeadline: New Unite chief threatens to cut Labour’s funding

attributes.value: Unite has threatened to withdraw funding from the Labour party as its new general secretary poured scorn on
Unite has threatened to withdraw funding from the Labour party as its new general secretary poured scorn on
Sir Keir Starmer’s shadow cabinet reshuffle
Sharon Graham warned the Labour leader that the union could cut its donations at a time when the party’s finances are under significant strain.

Graham said the resignation during the party conference of Andy McDonald, the last Corbynite in Starmer’s shadow cabinet, had sent out “not a good signal” and she dismissed this week’s reshuffle this week as “white noise”. Starmer promoted a number of younger MPs on
and appointed Yvette Cooper, the former Brownite minister, as shadow home secretary, and David Lammy, a former minister under Brown and Tony Blair, as shadow foreign secretary.

article.headline: West Side Story review — Steven Spielberg buoyantly reboots Bernstein’s classic
article.label: THE BIG FILM REVIEW
article.shortHeadline: West Side Story — Spielberg buoyantly reboots Bernstein’s classic

attributes.value: Typical Spielberg. Only he could manage to remake arguably the greatest musical of all time without falling flat on his
Typical Spielberg. Only he could manage to remake arguably the greatest musical of all time without falling flat on his face. On the contrary, he meets Bernstein and Sondheim’s

redux eye to eye, deftly shuffling a few numbers, adding a new character, dropping in a dash of political subtext, but otherwise approaching the spirit and the structure of the 1961 movie with unashamed reverence.

The frames thus drip with vintage Technicolor, as though they were recently unearthed from a Tinseltown vault. The 1950s New York locations are more 1950s than ever (courtesy of CGI augmentation). The standout songs are still ineffably poignant. The first rendition of
, between Ansel Elgort’s lovestruck Tony and Rachel Zegler’s Maria, will bring tears to

article.headline: Topps Tiles customer was grout of order
article.shortHeadline: Tile shop customer was grout of order

attributes.value: The customer is clearly not always right. Well not if you’re Garry Hardy, a shop manager who was sacked for accidentally
The customer is clearly not always right. Well not if you’re Garry Hardy, a shop manager who was sacked for accidentally splashing a cup of tea on the “world’s worst customer”.

in Sunderland, has won a legal challenge having claimed that he was unfairly dismissed because he had stood up to the “aggressive” and abusive customer to help a colleague during a heated dispute in November 2019.

An employment tribunal in Newcastle upon Tyne was told that the angry customer had accused them of being unable to “organise a piss up in a brewery” and had asked Hardy to step outside for a fight after wrongly claiming his order was late.
Hardy, who had asked the customer

article.headline: Careless older drivers need tests not points, say experts
article.shortHeadline: Careless older drivers ‘need tests not points’

attributes.value: Older drivers should be allowed to run red lights without being penalised, a government-funded report has said.
Older drivers should be allowed to run red lights without being penalised, a government-funded report has said.
The Older Drivers Task Force has called for over-70s to take a
test when they are caught driving recklessly, rather than face points on their licence, in an intervention that has been welcomed by motoring organisations.
Older drivers should take mandatory eye tests when they go to update their licence, a body of experts has said in an effort to reduce deaths of over-70s in crashes.

The report’s proposals, to be considered by ministers, state that trials should be set up to assess the benefits of fitness tests, and recommend that a scheme already running in Hampshire should be introduced nationally.
